Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Activity results: conversion (X, line) and selectivity (Y, bars) with temperature during LA hydrogenation over 6 %Cu-14 %Ni catalysts supported on various materials (a-e). Reaction conditions: 0.3 g catalyst, atmospheric pressure, liquid feed flowrate = 1.71 mL min−1, H2 flowrate = 60 mL min−1, LA:IPA molar ratio = 1:7; WHSV = 1.04 h−1. Characterization results: (f) NH3-TPD, (g) CO2-TPD, (h) GVL yield at 200 °C as a function of acid sites (AS) for 6 %Cu-14 %Ni catalysts, and (i) XRD spectra profiles. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Stability test: a) 10 h TOS and b) 42 h TOS of LA hydrogenation over CuNi/Al2O3. Reaction conditions: 200 °C, 0.1 g catalyst, liquid feed = 5.6 mL min−1, H2 = 60 mL min−1, LA:IPA = 1:7; WHSV = 9.4 h−1. Reactivation: H2 at 300 °C for 1 h. Characterization results: c) NH3-TPD, d) TPR, and e) XRD spectra. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Stability test: a) 10 h TOS and b) 42 h TOS of LA hydrogenation over Ni-Cu/SiO2-CA. The conversion of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is crucial for sustainable chemical and fuel production. This study evaluates the vapor phase hydrogenation of LA using Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts supported on various metal oxides and their impact on the pathways of LA conversion. Specifically, we examine the influence of AlO2, SiO2, ZrO2-SiO2, and CeO2-SiO2 on catalyst performance and stability. Cu-Ni catalysts supported on SiO2 modified with citric acid (SiO2-CA) exhibited superior stability, while the one supported on Al2O3 showed higher activity. The enhanced performance of the SiO2-CA-supported catalyst is attributed to its moderate acidity (379.3 µmol/gcat) and resistance to sintering. Stability tests reveal that although both CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA catalysts deactivate over time, the latter demonstrates slower deactivation and better reactivation potential, maintaining conversion close to 80 % for 42 h. The study highlights the role of support in optimizing catalytic performance for LA hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biomass-derived products Catalytic valorization Continuous hydrogenation Fuel additives Data Availability I have share the link of my Mendeley Dataset Mendeley Data Data of the vapor phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid over CuNi catalysts 1 Introduction The conversion of renewable resources, such as lignocellulosic biomass, into high-value chemicals is a promising alternative for sustainable production and the development of new energy models [1]. Therefore, the efficient utilization of biomass has recently received significant attention as a potential alternative to fossil fuels [2,3]. Among biomass-derived chemicals, levulinic acid (LA) is a molecule that can be obtained from lignocellulosic biomass through the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of C6 sugar carbohydrates (C6H12O6) into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and LA [4,5]. GF Biochemiclas has the largest commercial production of LA and reached 2000 MT/a in Caserta, Italy, followed by other projects such as Biofine and Segetis [6]. LA is a versatile chemical platform for the sustainable production of molecules like γ-valerolactone (GVL) [7], which is used in different industries including food, pharmaceuticals, and chemicals as a green solvent and second-generation biofuel [8]. However, GVL selectivity is limited by mass transfer due to the high viscosity of LA and the different pathways LA can follow depending on operation variables such as the hydrogen (H2) source, solvent, temperature, and catalyst [9]. Generally, this reaction is carried out in a liquid phase, batch process over noble-metal catalysts by the direct hydrogenation of the carbonyl group (CO) in the presence of either heterogeneous or homogeneous catalysts [10,11]. Direct hydrogenation employs molecular H2 at high pressures (> 10 bar) and expensive noble metal catalysts, such as Ru, Pd, Pt, and Ir, which have shown the highest activity [12]. Additionally, H2 has low solubility in the liquid phase; thus, higher pressures of H2 gas are required to improve the availability of molecular H2 in the presence of noble metal catalysts, which leads to higher conversions and yields [13]. However, the current batch conditions, expensive catalysts, and high H2 pressures imposed technical and economic limitations on large-scale implementation [8]. To improve the catalyst recovery and cost, the direct vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA using non-noble metal catalysts has been studied to develop a continuous process [14,15]. Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts have shown high activity and selectivity for continuous reactions among the tested materials. Yoshida et al. [14] reported a high LA conversion (96.1 %) and GVL selectivity (98.2 %) during the direct hydrogenation of LA at 250 °C and a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 13.2 h−1 over a 6 %Cu-14 %Ni/SiO2 catalyst, using citric acid (CA) as a chelating agent. Conversely, Yanase et al. [16] reported LA conversion > 90 % and 98.6 % GVL selectivity over Cu-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at 250 °C in vapor phase at WHSV of 6.6 h−1 for 96 h TOS. Characterization of the spent catalyst revealed deactivation due to sintering, primarily caused by the presence of H2O, and oxidation of the active particles [16]. In literature, one of the main challenges is the stability of the catalyst for LA hydrogenation in the vapor phase. Stability is crucial as catalyst properties can suffer alterations, primarily due to metal oxidation, shifts in acid-base distribution, coke deposition, and leaching after long periods [17,18]. The LA hydrogenation pathway over CuNi catalysts involves metallic, acidic, and basic sites, which influence process efficiency and resistance to deactivation [17,19,20]. Among the reported mechanisms, there are three main routes for the conversion of LA into GVL, summarized in Fig. 1 . First, the dehydration of LA leads to the formation of angelicalactones (ALs) and their subsequent reduction to GVL (Path 1 in Fig. 1) [21]. The second pathway involves the reduction of LA to 4-hydroxy valeric acid (4-HPA), a highly unstable intermediate, followed by its dehydration to GVL (Path 2 in Fig. 1) [19]. Another possible mechanism by which catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) occurs is via Meerwein−Ponndorf−Verley (MPV) reduction [22], with organic molecules or alcohols acting as renewable H2 sources (H-donors) (Path 3 in Fig. 1). In this case, alcohols such as isopropanol (IPA) can serve not only as solvents but also as H2 donors, improving GVL selectivity and LA conversion by promoting CTH. Also, depending on the reaction conditions, LA can crack into methyl ethyl ketone, 2-butanol, IPA, and acetone (Path 4 in Fig. 1) or the GVL can be further hydrogenated into butenes, valeric acid (VA) and 1–4 pentanediol (1–4 PDO) due to higher acidity (Path 5 in Fig. 1). The presence of acid and basic sites in the catalysts modulates the catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability [23]. This feature can be manipulated through the use of different supports, including aluminum oxide (Al2O3), silicon dioxide (SiO2), cerium oxide (CeO2), and zirconium (IV) oxide (ZrO2), as well as mixed oxides [24,25]. Al2O3, known for its acidic nature, can influence both the catalyst acidity and metal-support interactions [26,27]. SiO2 is known for its high surface area and thermal stability, which can affect metal dispersion and catalytic activity [28,29]. CeO2 [30] and ZrO2 [17], with their redox properties, introduce additional functionalities that impact catalytic performance. For instance, Zr-containing materials have shown promising activity results due to their acidic (Zr4+) and basic (O2-) characteristics, as well as their chemical stability [31]. Additionally, Zr-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs), such as Zr/MOFs and UiO-66 have shown enhanced selectivity through modifications in synthesis methods and the addition of -SO3H groups [32,33]. However, these materials still exhibit conversion and yield rates of 69 and 25 %, respectively [33]. ZrO2 supported on high-surface-area SBA-15 silica has been employed in the CTH of LA to GVL under both continuous [34] and batch [35] conditions. The effect of the catalyst's acid-base properties was analyzed, and it was observed that using Zr allowed for strong acid-base properties in the supported ZrO2(10)/SBA-15 catalyst compared to bulk ZrO2 catalysts, resulting in higher catalytic activity for CTH reactions [35]. During vapor phase CTH over a ZrO2/SBA-15 catalyst, a significant effect of ZrO2 loading on GVL selectivity was observed [34]. It was confirmed that strong acidity is necessary for effective CTH, achieved by increasing the ZrO2 loading from 10 % to 25 %, which resulted in a selectivity increase from 59 % to 93 % [34]. Also, a bimetallic NiCe catalyst was tested in LA vapor phase hydrogenation. The presence of CeO2 in the catalyst improves metal dispersion and prevents the sintering of noble metals by forming Ni─O─Ce structures [30]. Despite recent studies on vapor phase LA hydrogenation, the low stability of active Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts limits the scale-up of continuous processes. In this context, a better understanding of metal-support interaction can contribute to design strategies to enhance catalyst stability. This research studied the metal-support interaction of bimetallic Ni-Cu catalyst over different supports, including AlO2, SiO2, and two mixed supports (i.e., ZrO2-SiO2 and CeO2-SiO2), during LA hydrogenation in continuous vapor phase using H2 as a reductant and carrier gas and IPA as a solvent. Stability tests were conducted on samples exhibiting higher activity and selectivity under optimal conditions over 42 h of time-on-stream (TOS). Recovery of catalytic activity was achieved after catalyst reactivation at the reduction temperature for 1 h in H2. Several characterization techniques were used to understand the changes in the chemical and physical properties and the effect on its activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The supports used included SiO2 (Sigma, Aldrich with a mean pore diameter < 75 µm, SBET = 295 m2g−1), ɣ-Al2O3 (Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %, USA), CeO2 obtained by calcination of Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5 %, USA), and ZrO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %). These supports were calcined at 500 °C in a muffle furnace for 3 h prior to use. The active metals were obtained from Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu (NO3)2·3H2O) and Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) dissolved in water. Based on the prior studies of Yanase et al. [16] and Yoshida et al. [14], citric acid (C₆H₈O₇) was used as a chelating agent for catalysts supported on based SiO2, CeO2, and ZrO2 to enhance catalytic performance and acidity. The molar ratio of citric acid to the total amount of Cu and Ni metals was maintained at 1. For catalysts supported on Al₂O₃, citric acid was not used to preserve the support’s intrinsic acidity. The metal loadings for Cu and Ni were 6 wt% and 14 wt%, respectively, following the findings of these studies, where this ratio was identified as the most active for LA hydrogenation [14,16]. The required quantities of metal precursors and, when applicable, citric acid solution, were impregnated onto the supports. The samples were then dried at 100 °C for 24 h and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. To ensure uniformity, all calcined solids were sieved through a 220-mesh sieve, resulting in particle sizes < 75 µm. The nomenclature for the catalyst samples is as follows: CuNi/Al2O3, CuNi/SiO2, CuNi/SiO2-CA, CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA and CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA, where the subscript CA indicates the use of CA as a chelating agent during synthesis. All dual-oxide supports were synthesized by the impregnation method at equimolar ratios prior to the metal impregnation step. 2.2 Catalytic evaluation LA hydrogenation was carried out in a tubular fixed-bed reactor (ID=12 mm) as described in previous works [36,37]. IPA was used as a solvent, with a LA:IPA molar ratio of 1:7 [14], this alcoholic solution was pumped to the reactor using a syringe pump (MedCaptain MP-30, China) and mixed with H2 gas (60 mL min−1), which served as both the reductant and carrier gas. The reaction temperature and WHSV varied between 200 and 300 °C and 1–17.4 h−1, respectively. All catalytic tests were conducted at atmospheric pressure. Initial catalytic tests were performed under a WHSV of 1.04 h−1, starting the reaction at the maximum temperature of 300 °C and reducing the temperature by 25 °C until reaching 200 °C. To assess the role of IPA as an H₂ donor in the context of CTH, experiments were conducted using N₂ as the carrier gas. The results, shown in Figure S1 of Supplementary Material, demonstrate that while IPA facilitates LA hydrogenation, the presence of H₂ gas is crucial for achieving higher conversion rates and selectivity. Additionally, some catalyst samples were subjected to stability tests at 200 °C under a WHSV of 9.4 h−1. Before each experiment, the samples were reduced at 500 °C for 1 h in H2 (50 mL min−1), except for the Al2O3 catalyst, which was reduced at 300 °C for 1 h in H2 (50 mL min−1). Reduced samples are referred to as “fresh (F)” catalysts. The plug flow reactor condition was satisfied by ensuring a ratio of catalyst bed height to catalyst particle size (L/Dp) and a ratio of reactor internal diameter to catalyst particle size (D/Dp), both higher than 60 [38]. The reactor products were condensed in an ice-cold bath every hour and collected in 15 mL acetonitrile (ACN), which was used as a solvent for the product mixture. Samples of 1 mL with 100 µl of isoamyl alcohol as internal standard were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) in a Clarus 580 (Perkin Elmer, USA) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-WAXETR column (60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The GC oven temperature was programmed to increase from 80 to 110 °C at a rate of 15 °C min−1, held for 1 min, then further heated to 230 °C at a rate of 8 °C min−1, and held for 15 min. Components were identified by comparison with calibration curves from known standards. The conversion of each species (LA and IPA) and the product distribution of each species (ALs, GVL, VA, 1–4 PDO, 2-HMF, 5-MFFR, and other byproducts), selectivity, space-time yield (STY), and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated from Eqs. 1–5 as follows: (1) LA conversion % = n LA in − n LA out n LA in * 100 (2) Product selectivit y i [ % ] = n i out ∑ n i out * 100 (3) WHSV h − 1 = F LA W cat (4) STY kg GVL kg cat − 1 h − 1 = n GVL out * M W GVL W cat * t (5) TOF s − 1 = − r A f m = Initial reaction rate [ mol * s − 1 g cat − 1 ] Surface moles of active material per unit weight of catalyst [ mol g cat − 1 ] Where, n LA in and n LA out are the initial and final mol flowrate of LA [mol h−1], respectively. n i out is the outlet mol flowrate of product i [mol h−1], W cat is the catalyst weight, FLA is the mass flowrate of LA [g h−1], M W GVL is the molecular weight of GVL and t is the reaction time. The fm were calculated using metal dispersion determined from TEM results (see Eq. 8). All reagent manipulations were carried out under the internal laboratory protocols for the handling and storage of chemical substances. Finally, to evaluate reproducibility, some experiments were randomly repeated under optimized conditions, ensuring a variation in conversion, selectivity, and yields of less than 5 % between experiments. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The synthesized, reduced samples (Fresh), those obtained after stability tests (Spent), and after reactivation tests (Reactivated) were characterized by different techniques. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD, respectively), Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) and Specific surface area (SBET) were determined in a ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD (Quantachrome Instruments, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the NH3/CO2−TPD, approximately 0.1 ± 0.01 g sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz cell and reduced at 500 °C for 1 h in a 50 mL min−1 of H2 flowrate before each experiment. Subsequently, H2 was purged from the catalyst using a 50 mL min−1 He stream for 30 min. The catalyst surface was saturated with the probe molecule NH3 or CO2 (flow rate of 50 mL min−1 of 5 vol% NH3/N2 or 5 vol% CO2/N2) at 80 ºC for 1 h. The sample was purged with N2 or He (50 mL min−1) for 30 min to eliminate the physically adsorbed probe molecules. TPD was performed by increasing temperature from 25–1000 °C at 10 °C min−1. The desorbed molecules were detected using a TCD. For H2−TPR and TPO, approximately 0.1 ± 0.01 g of sample was heated from room temperature to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flowing stream of 10 vol% H2/N2 or 2 vol% O2/N2 (50 mL min−1). The reduction process was conducted for 1 hour before each experiment. The catalyst was then purged with a 50 mL min−1 He stream for 30 minutes to remove excess H2. Specific surface area (SBET) was calculated by using the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method, in a ChemBET Pulsar (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL, USA). 70 mg of sample was previously degassed in He (50 mL/min) at 120 °C for 1 h; surface area was measured at liquid nitrogen temperature with 30 % N2/He (50 mL/min) as the adsorption gas. The measurement was repeated until a deviation lower than 5 % was obtained. The crystal structure of the catalysts was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The relative crystallinity percentage of the zeolites was determined by the sum of the area of the crystalline peaks over the total sum of peaks (crystalline + amorphous) [36,37]. The diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker (D8 ADVANCE, USA) diffractometer. For this, spectra were recorded at 2θ in the range of 10° − 90° with a step size of 0.05° and a peak position deviation of ≤ 0.002°. The crystallite size of the samples was calculated by the Sherrer equation, Eq. 6: (6) D [ nm ] = k λ β cos θ Where k is the Debye-Sherrer constant (0.9), λ is the wavelength, β is the line broadening at half the maximum intensity (FWHM), and θ is the Bragg’s angle [39]. The morphology and structural properties of the catalysts were evaluated by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) (TECNAI G2 F20 microscope, USA) at 200 kV, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX), and selected area electron diffraction (SAED). For this, samples were sonicated for 20 min in ethanol and deposited on an Au grid. The micrographs obtained were employed to measure the diameter of the active metal particles using ImageJ software. At least 210 particles were counted per sample. The average surface-area-weighted diameter ( d s ̅ ) of the active metal particles (Cu and Ni) was calculated according to Eq. 7 [40]. Also, the metallic dispersion (D) was determined according to Eq.8 [41]. (7) d s ̅ [ nm ] = ∑ i n i d i 3 ∑ i n i d i 2 (8) D % = 1 d s ̅ [ nm ] * 100 % where n i is the number of particles and d i is the particle diameter. Dispersion values were used to calculate the surface moles of active material (see Eq. 5). While TEM has limitations in distinguishing between Cu and Ni due to their similar atomic weights, it remains a widely accepted technique for analyzing particle dispersion in catalysis. In this study, over 210 particles per sample were analyzed to ensure statistical robustness, yielding reliable surface-area-weighted diameters and dispersion values. These results are consistent with established methodologies reported in the literature [40,41] All raw and processed Excel data from catalytic activity and catalyst characterization results can be downloaded from [dataset] [42]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Impact of CuNi catalyst properties on vapor phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid The vapor phase LA hydrogenation was investigated using various CuNi-supported catalysts at different reaction temperatures. Fig. 2 presents the activity and selectivity results along with relevant catalyst properties. Al2O3 has been identified as a promising support for LA dehydrogenation due to its ability to enhance GVL selectivity [16,43]. Incorporating active metals such as Cu and Ni is critical to achieving higher activity and enhancing GVL selectivity. Activity tests conducted with bare supports (SiO2 and Al2O3), presented in the Supplementary Material (Figure S2), showed that Al2O3 achieved 20 % GVL selectivity but exhibited lower LA conversion. This behavior can be attributed to its intrinsic acidity, which promotes dehydration and hydrogenation reactions (Path 1 in Fig. 1). However, the absence of active metals significantly limited its overall catalytic performance. In contrast, bare SiO2 displayed minimal activity (Figure 2Sa), primarily producing Als, mainly formed through LA dehydration. These findings underscore the importance of incorporating active metal phases and achieving a balanced acidity-basicity in the support to optimize GVL production. Fig. 2 a shows that the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst predominantly yields GVL, with minor amounts of AL, VA, and other by-products (e.g., 2-butanone, acetone, 2-butanol, ethyl valerates, furans, etc.), achieving a maximum GVL selectivity of ⁓77.9 % at 250 °C. In contrast, CuNi/SiO2 (Fig. 2 b) promoted the formation of AL and other by-products, yielding only a 13 % selectivity to GVL at 300 °C. The addition of a chelating agent to SiO2, as proposed by Yoshida et al. [14], enhances particle dispersion and catalytic performance in GVL production. Fig. 2 c depicts the selectivity of the CuNi/SiO2, with the inclusion of CA as a chelating agent (CuNi/SiO2-CA). The presence of CA significantly enhances GVL selectivity (> 30 %) across the entire temperature range, achieving superior selectivity (85.6 % at 200 °C) compared to CuNi/Al2O3. However, GVL selectivity decreases with temperature as higher temperatures favor AL formation through dehydration reaction (path 1 in Fig. 1) [34]. Thus, CuNi/SiO2-CA shows predominant GVL formation at lower temperatures (Fig. 2 c), indicating a preference for hydrogenation and lactonization processes (Path 2 in Fig. 1) facilitated by enhanced metallic and acid sites within the catalyst [17]. Consequently, the inclusion of CA modifies catalyst properties, improving the performance of the SiO2-based catalysts, as further discussed in subsequent sections. Another approach for tuning the acidity and basicity of supports is the incorporation of a second oxide. Fig. 2 d and e show the selectivity of CuNi catalysts supported on a dual matrix of CeO2-SiO2-CA and ZrO2-SiO2-CA. SiO2 was synthesized with CA as a chelating agent in both cases. GVL selectivity decreases and by-products (VA, AL, and others) selectivity increases over both materials, suggesting potential hydrogenation of GVL to form VA and 1,4-Pentanediol, esterification (i.e., levulinates), and LA cracking products (See Path 4 and Path 5 in Fig. 1) [6,44,45]. This suggests that incorporating CeO2 and ZrO2 as co-supports with SiO2-CA induces changes in the catalyst, thereby impacting the GVL selectivity. CuNi catalysts supported on the different oxides also exhibited variations in their activity. Fig. 2 a shows that CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst enhances its activity with temperature, attributed to the favorable cracking of LA at elevated temperatures (> 250 °C) [43] (Path 4 in Fig. 1), achieving 100 % conversion at 300 °C. These results are in line with those reported in the literature, showing that vapor-phase LA hydrogenation can result in higher reaction rates compared to liquid-phase batch processes. The last process requires up to 4 h to achieve > 60 % conversions with CuNi-based catalysts [46]. Fig. 2 b demonstrates that the activity trend of CuNi/SiO2 is similar to CuNi/Al2O3; however, CuNi/SiO2 exhibits lower activity compared to CuNi/Al2O3. In contrast, the use of a chelating agent in the synthesis of SiO2 enhances the activity of CuNi/SiO2-CA, ensuring conversions exceeding 73 % even at low temperatures (< 250 °C). The activity of CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst was enhanced by 60 % compared to CuNi/SiO2, attributed to improve its moderate acid density. Thus, CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst is promising for obtaining GVL at low temperatures with LA conversions surpassing those obtained either in batch processes or over the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst. Regarding dual-oxide supported catalysts, Fig. 2 d shows that the CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA catalyst exhibits the lowest activity among the tested catalysts, achieving no more than 23 % LA conversion even at 250 °C. However, Fig. 2 e shows that the CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA catalyst displays the highest activity among the evaluated materials, ensuring LA conversions above 76 % from 200 °C. In any case, both dual catalysts, i.e., CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA and CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA, show lower GVL selectivity compared to CuNi/SiO2-CA. Despite this, the high conversion of CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA could be of interest to other LA utilization processes. The variations in selectivity and activity observed among the different CuNi catalysts can be linked to changes in their properties. Therefore, the following discussion examines how the characteristics of the evaluated materials may elucidate the results observed in the activity tests (Fig. 2 a-e). As discussed previously, the tunable acidity-basicity of catalysts used in LA hydrogenation plays a central role in GVL production. The total amount and strength of the acid and basic sites on the catalyst's surface after reduction were assessed by NH3/CO2-TPD. Desorption profiles are shown in Fig. 2 f and g, while the total amount of desorbed NH3/CO2 was summarized in Table 1. Acidity profiles can be divided into three main regions, which indicate the presence of weak (W) (80–150 °C), moderate (M) (150–400 °C), and strong (S) acid sites (>400 °C) [47]. Among all samples, the W and M acid sites exhibited the largest distribution, with the total amount of acid sites decreasing in the following order: CuNi/ZrO₂-SiO₂-CA > CuNi/Al₂O₃ > CuNi/SiO₂-CA > CuNi/SiO₂ > CuNi/CeO₂-SiO₂-CA. As anticipated, CuNi/Al2O3 exhibited a high W and M acid sites, consistent with the well-documented intrinsic acidity of Al₂O₃. This heightened acidity is attributed to the presence of surface hydroxyl groups capable of generating both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [48]. In contrast, SiO2 is predominantly neutral, with its limited acidity primarily arising from surface silanol groups [49]. This marked difference in acidity accounts for the higher density of weak and moderate acid sites observed in Al₂O₃-supported catalysts compared to those supported on SiO₂. Popova et al. [43] highlighted the crucial role of acidic sites in Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst in enhancing GVL selectivity and LA conversion. They demonstrated how these acidic sites facilitate dehydration and synergize with Ni to bolster hydrogenation processes. Therefore, the moderate acidity observed in CuNi/Al2O3 can be correlated with its notable GVL selectivity (Fig. 2 a). In contrast, the lower total acidity of CuNi/SiO2, which is less than half that of CuNi/Al2O3, would be linked to the reduced both GVL selectivity and LA conversion. Notably, the inclusion of CA as a chelating agent increased the total acidity of CuNi/SiO₂-CA to levels comparable to CuNi/Al₂O₃, with only an 8.9 % difference. Previous studies have identified CA as a modifier of CuNi particle size and distribution [14]. However, these results suggest an additional effect on the catalyst’s acidity. The significantly higher moderate acid site density in CuNi/SiO₂-CA (3.9 times greater than that of CuNi/SiO₂) is directly associated with its enhanced activity and GVL selectivity, as demonstrated in Fig. 2 h. On the other hand, CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA exhibited the lowest total acidity among evaluated catalysts, affecting its GVL selectivity (Fig. 2 d). Liang et al. [30] reported that CeNi interactions in Ni/SiO2 catalysts for LA hydrogenation improve activity. Our study indicates that the significant reduction in acidity likely hindered catalytic performance. According to Popova et al. [43], insufficient acidic sites can limit the interaction between the support and active sites, drastically reducing LA hydrogenation efficiency. Thus, CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA exhibited the lowest activity and GVL selectivity. In contrast, CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA catalysts exhibited the highest number of acid sites, likely due to the formation of Si-O-Zr bridging bonds, which increase the density of M and S acid sites [45]. Despite their high acidity and higher LA conversion, CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA displayed low GVL selectivity as seen in Fig. 2 e. Fig. 2 h correlates the acidity of the catalysts with the GVL yield. The volcano shape demonstrates that intermediate acidity levels, such as those found in SiO2-CA and Al2O3 supports, favor GVL production. Extremely low or high acidity levels are less favorable, with catalysts exhibiting lower acidity, such as CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA, showing lower GVL selectivity due to a lower dehydration capacity [17]. While the impact of high acidity catalysts on LA hydrogenation performance remains debated, acidity regulation is conducted to prevent coke formation and minimize by-product formation from the formed GVL (e.g., valeric acid and hydrocarbons) [50]. Also, Hengne et al. [20] reported that acid supports can favor the formation of ethyl levulinates through esterification reactions and other hydrogenated byproducts of GVL in the presence of solvents. While Enumula et al. [34] suggested that further increasing the number of acid sites (2.18 mmol NH3 gcat −1) decreases GVL selectivity due to the formation of ring-opening products from GVL hydrogenation and dehydration products of LA. Nonetheless, results with dual supports confirm that excessively low acidity can impact GVL selectivity, as in the case of CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA, while a very high acidity can also diminish selectivity, as observed with CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA. These results support the need to avoid catalysts with extreme acidity during LA hydrogenation [51]. The quantity and strength of basic sites presented in Table 1 and CO2 desorption profiles (Fig. 2 g) show that catalysts varied in basicity, decreasing in the following order: CuNi/SiO2-CA > CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA > CuNi/Al2O3 > CuNi/SiO2 > CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA. All samples presented two main peaks in the range of 80–400 °C, assigned to W and M basic sites, and a small peak at temperatures > 400 °C for S basic sites [47]. The most selective catalysts towards GVL (i.e., CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA) exhibited differences in their basicity. CuNi/Al2O3 possesses a moderate total basicity (215 µmol/gcat), while the one for CuNi/SiO2-CA is 60 % higher. This indicates that, unlike acidity, where moderate values are recommended, no clear trend links basicity to improved GVL selectivity or LA conversion. However, the presence of the CA chelating agent increased the basicity of CuNi/SiO2-CA, surpassing that on CuNi/SiO2 by a factor of 2.5, particularly in M-type basicity. Although no specific optimal range for basicity in LA hydrogenation has been established, low basicity levels can negatively affect GVL selectivity. In SiO2-CA-based catalysts, the introduction of a second oxide reduces overall basicity while altering the distribution of basic species. Specifically, CuNi/CeO₂-SiO₂-CA exhibits a notable decrease in M-type basic sites, whereas CuNi/ZrO₂-SiO₂-CA shows a reduction in W-type basic species, both relative to CuNi/SiO₂-CA (see Table 1). This decline in basicity aligns with the findings of Gao et al. [45], who reported that ZrO₂-SiO₂ supports generally exhibit lower basicity and higher acidity than pure ZrO₂, attributed to the formation of Zr-O-Si bonds. The role of basic sites in catalytic performance remains a topic of ongoing discussion. However, Wang et al. [52] suggested that the generation of O2- species over basic sites may the formation of reaction intermediates, triggering a cascade of dehydration and intramolecular esterification reactions that ultimately enhance GVL production. Additionally, basic sites could synergize with acidic sites, favoring the activation of the carbonyl groups (CO) of LA and promoting MPV reduction through the CTH (See Path 3 in Fig. 1) [12]. For instance, Kuwahara et al. [51] investigated a Ru(OH)x/ɣ-Al2O3 catalyst for LA CTH, achieving an 80 % conversion of the methyl ester intermediate of 4-HPM and promoting the formation of GVL through dealcoholization, particularly in the presence of basic sites (path 2 in Fig. 1). Komanoya et al. [53] emphasized the role of acidic and basic sites in the MPV mechanism, highlighting that acidic sites have a stronger influence than basic sites. Catalysts with higher concentrations of both strong acid and basic sites (e.g., ZrO2) exhibit superior catalytic performance compared to those containing only acid sites (e.g., TiO2 and Nb2O5). This advantage stems from the critical role of strong acid sites in facilitating the initial formation of six-membered intermediates within Lewis acid sites [53]. Although the results remain inconclusive, our findings suggest that M-type basic sites play a more significant role in catalyst performance during LA hydrogenation, indicating that a moderate to high density of basic sites is essential for enhancing GVL selectivity. The findings of this study confirm the crucial role of catalyst acidity and basicity in LA hydrogenation. However, these factors alone do not fully account for the observed trends in selectivity and activity over CuNi catalysts, prompting further investigation into additional catalyst properties. Table 1 presents the surface area of supported CuNi catalysts, revealing no direct correlation with GVL yield. This aligns with the observations of Balla et al. [54], who found no clear relationship between catalyst activity and surface area when studying various Cu catalysts supported on Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2, and TiO2 [54]. Furthermore, as shown in Table 1, the SiO2-CA-based catalysts exhibit a relatively high surface area (324 m²/g), which enhances CuNi particle dispersion and reduces agglomeration. This effect increases the density of accessible active sites, ultimately improving both activity and selectivity towards GVL. In contrast, the incorporation of secondary oxides (CeO2 and ZrO2) into the SiO2-CA supports resulted in a significant reduction in surface area (44 % and 31 % decreases, respectively). This suggests that these oxides partially block the silica pores, limiting the exposure of active sites and negatively affecting catalytic activity. Despite its lower surface area, the CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA catalyst demonstrated high LA conversion due to its elevated total acidity, attributed to the formation of Si-O-Zr bridging bonds [30]. For the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst, in spite of its lower surface area (103 m²/g), high catalytic activity was observed, underscoring the importance of other structural factors such as the density and distribution of acidic sites and the formation of CuNi phases. These results highlight that surface area, while important, is not the sole determinant of catalytic performance. Fig. 2 i shows the XRD patterns of the CuNi catalysts, while Table 1 presents the crystalline size of the CuNi bimetallic phase, which predominates in all samples. The crystal size followed the order CuNi/SiO2-CA > CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA > CuNi/SiO2 > CuNi/Al2O3 > CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA, although this parameter does not correlate with catalytic activity and selectivity. The characteristic peaks of the supports were observed in the XRD patterns. For the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst, peaks at 44.2°, 51.4°, and 75.9° were primarily attributed to CuNi bimetallic phases, as these lie between the characteristic Ni metal peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.6° (JCPDS 04–0850) [55] and Cu metal peaks at 2θ = 43.4°, 50.5°, and 74.3° (JCPDS 04–0836) [19]. CuNi phases formation has been reported to prevent metal sintering and leaching while promoting H2 dissociative adsorption, which enhances catalytic performance during hydrogenation reactions [56]. In addition to the CuNi phases, small peaks at 38.7° and 66.2° were assigned to CuO or NiO phases and metallic Ni. These phases are consistent with previous reports [57], which suggest that mixed Cu and Ni phases, including oxidized forms, can coexist in bimetallic catalysts. The presence of multiple Ni phases in CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst may enhance the interaction of Ni with Al2O3 improving Ni dispersion and increasing the catalyst’s ability to dehydrogenate and form Als [50]. The CuNi/SiO2 catalyst exhibited peaks related only to CuNi phases (See Fig. 2 h). While the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst presented additional peaks corresponding to oxidized phases of Ni and Cu metals. The CA promoted the formation of NiO and CuO phases, which likely contributed to the enhanced activity and selectivity observed for CuNi/SiO2-CA. The presence of the NiO phase has been reported to influence catalytic performance in LA hydrogenation, particularly when alcohols are used as solvents. For instance, IPA can undergo oxidation over NiO, facilitating dehydrogenation and generating additional H2, which becomes available for hydride formation at the metal sites [16]. Regarding the mixed supported catalysts, CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA showed only the lattice planes of CuNi phases. The absence of NiO and CuO phases might explain its lower catalytic activity, as previously discussed. Likewise, the CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA catalyst showed peaks corresponding to NiO and CuO, which may improve its activity, but its higher acidity affected GVL selectivity, likely promoting side reactions. To further understand the role of Cu and Ni in the bimetallic system, catalytic tests were conducted using single-metal catalysts supported on Al2O3 and SiO2-CA with 20 % of total metal loading, as these supports showed the highest GVL yield at lower temperature in bimetallic systems. The results presented in Figure S3 (Supplementary Material) show that single-phase Ni exhibits superior performance at higher temperatures (>250 °C), likely due to its ability to effectively facilitate both dehydrogenation and hydrogenation steps, as previously reported by Mallesham et al. [58]. In contrast, single-phase Cu demonstrates moderate GVL selectivity but limited activity, particularly at lower temperatures (<250 °C). These findings align with the work of García-Sancho et al. [59], which emphasized the role of Cu in hydrogenating intermediates. As a result, the synergy within the CuNi system becomes essential for enhancing both GVL selectivity and LA conversion at lower temperatures, highlighting the importance of cooperative interactions between the two metals. The above results highlight the critical role of acidity and basicity in the activity and selectivity of CuNi supported catalysts for LA hydrogenation. The results demonstrate that an optimal balance of acidic and basic sites is essential for maximizing GVL yield, as evidenced by the superior performance of CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA. The formation of CuNi bimetallic phase, the presence of oxidized phases, and specific interactions with supports like Al2O3 and SiO2-CA significantly influence catalytic performance. These insights provide a foundation for understanding how modifying a catalyst’s physical and chemical properties can enhance LA hydrogenation processes. The following section will show stability tests for CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA samples, building on the significant findings outlined above. 3.2 Stability of the CuNi catalysts during the vapor phase LA hydrogenation The stability of CuNi catalyst supported on Al2O3 and SiO2-CA was tested at WHSV of 9.4 h−1. This WHSV was selected to closely simulate conditions relevant to scaled-up industrial processes. Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 show the results combined with some characterization data. Fig. 3 a shows the results of the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst, regarding LA stability, GVL selectivity, and STY over 10 h TOS. There is an evident decline in activity and GVL STY after 3 h TOS over the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst. Kondeboina et al. [27] conducted a study on the deactivation of the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst during LA hydrogenation, which reduced its activity after 5 h of TOS. They observed stability enhancement by including a second metal (3Ni17Co/γ-Al2O3). However, the catalyst’s activity decreases after 9 h TOS due to strong acidity that favors cracking reactions (Path 4 in Fig. 1). Similarly, Putrakumar et al. [26] found comparable results over a Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, attributing deactivation to sintering and coke deposition. Thus, alumina-supported catalyst deactivation is predominantly linked to the formation of angelica lactones (Path 1 in Fig. 1), which is favored by the acidity of the catalyst, which can generate carbonaceous species that deactivate the material. Therefore, the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst was subjected to prevent regeneration by in situ reduction at the same conditions as the initial ones, 300 °C every 5 h, to regenerate the material. Fig. 3 b shows the results after 6 reactivation cycles up to 42 h TOS. However, CuNi/Al2O3 was completely deactivated after 32 h TOS. Hence, H2 reduction cycles did not restore the activity of the catalyst. CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst was subjected to the same process (Fig. 4 a). Rapid deactivation of the catalyst and even lower STY (3 kg GVL kg−1 cat h−1) were also observed. On the other hand, Fig. 4 b shows the results of preventing regeneration of CuNi/SiO2-CA catalysts by in situ reduction at 500 °C every 5 h. CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst maintained its activity and STY throughout the 42 h TOS, with a constant selectivity of 98 %. Therefore, reduction cycles helped to maintain the performance of the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst. Catalyst characterizations were carried out on the fresh, spent, and reactivated samples to analyze this behavior. Figs. 3 c and 4 c show the NH3-TPD profiles of fresh, spent, and reactivated catalysts. The NH3-TPD profile of the CuNi/Al2O3 spent sample exhibits strong Al2O3 acidity compared to the fresh sample (See total acidity in Table 2), showing peaks at higher temperatures values (400–900 °C). This increase in acidity may be related to several aspects, including oxidation, the presence of organic compounds on the catalyst surface, or the presence of IPA, which has been reported to acidify the catalyst surface and modify its activity [60,61]. This change is particularly notable in W-type sites, which increases 12 times compared to the fresh sample profile [17]. The increase in acidity is not reversible after regeneration, as seen in Fig. 3 c. The CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst also shows an increase in acidity after use (Fig. 4 c), with W and S sites increasing by 44 and 25 times, respectively. However, in this case, the regeneration process was able to return the acidity to similar values of the fresh sample (Fig. 4 c, reactivated sample), which explains the activity recovery during the stability test. TPR profiles of the fresh-reduced, spent, and reactivated CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst samples are shown in Figs. 3 d and 4 d, respectively. The TPR profile of the fresh-reduced CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a reduction peak at about 500 °C (See Fig. 3 d). However, the spent sample showed significant changes in reducibility, with an increase in the H2-uptake (Table 2), increasing the peaks above 400 °C. Thus, the active particles are being oxidized and their interaction with the support is increased [62,63], this behavior is not reversible as can be noted in Fig. 3 d. TPR profiles of the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst (Fig. 4 d) also showed a reduction peak shift to higher temperatures after use, with a new reduction peak close to 500 °C. However, reactivation cycles facilitate the recovery of the initial active site distribution [26,64], also confirmed by the H2 uptake after reactivation cycles. XRD results showed changes in the crystal structure of the samples, Figs. 3 e and 4 e, which coincide with the observations made in the other characterization techniques. A reduction in the size of the CuNi alloy crystals and an increase in the peaks corresponding to the Ni and Cu metal phases were observed over the Al2O3 catalyst (Table 2 ). Also, the peaks related to the NiO and CuO phases disappeared, which may also explain the failure of the H2 reduction to reactivate this catalyst. Therefore, CuNi/SiO2-CA exhibits specific acid/base properties and an optimal metal distribution that enhances its catalytic performance, showing its potential as for prolonged catalytic reactions in LA conversion processes. TPO results for the CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA catalysts reveal significant differences in oxygen consumption and weight loss, as summarized in Table 2. For the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst, the spent sample exhibited higher oxygen consumption compared to the fresh sample, accompanied by a weight loss of 12.6 wt%. This increased oxygen consumption and substantial weight loss suggest the formation of coke on the catalyst surface, leading to a blockage of active sites [27,65]. In contrast, the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst showed higher oxygen consumption in the fresh sample than in the spent sample, with a minimal weight loss of 2.4 wt%. This indicates that the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst experiences less coke formation and retains more of its active sites during the reaction, contributing to its better performance and stability. The morphology and particle size distribution of the CuNi catalyst were analyzed using TEM/EDX, HR-TEM, and SADP, as shown in Figs. 5 and 6. The fresh CuNi/Al₂O₃ catalyst exhibited spherical metallic particles with an average size of 66.1 nm. Elemental mapping (Fig. 5) revealed a homogeneous distribution of Cu and Ni, which can be attributed to their corresponding nanoparticles and the possible presence of a bimetallic phase. In contrast, after 42 h TOS, the particle size of the spent catalyst increased significantly to 160.4 nm. Similarly, the reactivated catalyst showed a particle size increase to 162.2 nm. EDS analysis confirmed the agglomeration of Ni and Cu metal particles, with a reduced presence of Al and O from the support. This particle size growth, likely caused by sintering, is consistent with previously reported findings and may explain the observed decline in selectivity [16]. An increase in particle size was also observed for the CuNi/SiO₂-CA catalyst after use, with the size increasing from 29.34 nm to 92.74 nm (Fig. 6). However, this sintering occurred gradually, allowing the active sites that remained functional after reactivation to sustain conversion and selectivity over time. Notably, the reactivated CuNi/SiO₂-CA sample maintained a consistent metal distribution, suggesting a stronger metal-support interaction. Regarding the SADP results for the CuNi/Al₂O₃ and CuNi/SiO₂-CA catalysts, no significant changes in the calculated d-spacing were observed across the three samples (Figs. 5 c and 6 c). However, the spent catalyst exhibited fewer rings and spots compared to the fresh sample, indicating a reduction in the crystallinity of the active particles. These changes in crystallinity may influence catalytic performance, as crystallinity affects the availability and reactivity of active sites. Additionally, TOF values were calculated from TEM results using Eq. 8 . The TOF values for the CuNi/Al₂O₃ and CuNi/SiO₂-CA catalysts were 0.311 and 0.099 s⁻¹ , respectively, indicating that larger particles (as observed in the CuNi/Al₂O₃ catalyst) enhance reaction effectiveness. These TOF results are comparable to those reported for Ru catalysts [66,67] and exceed those reported for Ni and Cu catalysts [68–70], both tested in batch reactors. The stability of CuNi catalysts during vapor phase hydrogenation of LA has shown significant variations depending on the support used. The results indicate that the CuNi/Al2O3 catalyst rapidly deactivates after 3 h TOS due to the preferential formation of ALs and coke deposition, which cannot be effectively reversed through H2 reduction cycles. In contrast, the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst maintains its activity and 98 % selectivity over 42 h TOS, demonstrating that regeneration cycles are effective in restoring the original catalytic properties. Characterizations such as NH3-TPD, TPR, TPO, and TEM/EDX confirm that the greater stability of CuNi/SiO2-CA is due to its lower coke formation, effective recovery of active site distribution after regeneration, and stronger metal-support interaction. Therefore, CuNi/SiO2-CA emerges as a promising catalyst. The results of this study were compared with previous reports, as summarized in Table 3. Unlike most studies that utilized H₂ and water as solvents at temperatures exceeding 250 °C [16,27,30], we used IPA as both the solvent and hydrogen donor in the vapor phase. This approach allowed for operation at lower temperatures, preventing LA solidification and achieving conversion rates above 95 %. Space-time yield obtained in this study was comparable to values reported in the literature, with the added advantage of being achieved at lower temperatures and in the vapor phase. Our findings also revealed that Al₂O₃-based catalysts were irreversibly deactivated due to rapid active metal sintering and the accumulation of strong carbon deposits. In contrast, SiO₂-based catalysts demonstrated the potential for preventive reactivation, enabling prolonged continuous operation. This extended operational analysis, which has not been previously reported, is critical for developing industrial catalysts for this reaction, where catalyst deactivation remains the primary challenge. 4 Conclusions This study explored the vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL using 6 %Cu-14 %Ni catalysts supported on different metal oxides and under several operating conditions, with IPA as both solvent and hydrogen donor. Results suggest that employing SiO2 as a support, especially with Ca as a chelating agent, is advantageous over Al2O3. The CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst demonstrated moderate acidity, enhanced basicity, a slight increase in surface area, and the presence of NiO and CuO phases, resulting in improved LA conversion and GVL selectivity. The incorporation of CeO2 and ZrO2 into the CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst produced mixed results. The CuNi/CeO2-SiO2-CA catalyst exhibited a significant drop-in activity due to the presence of CeO2, which affected GVL selectivity. In contrast, CuNi/ZrO2-SiO2-CA displayed increased activity but lower GVL selectivity, emphasizing the importance of moderate acidity for achieving optimal selectivity in LA hydrogenation. These results underscore the critical need for precisely tailored catalyst compositions to enhance performance in this process. Stability tests on CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA catalysts, which showed superior activity and selectivity, revealed rapid deactivation. Reactivation tests identified oxidation and sintering of active metals as primary causes, increasing average surface particle sizes from 66 to 162 nm for CuNi/Al2O3 and from 29 to 96 nm for CuNi/SiO2-CA after reactivation cycles. CuNi/SiO2-CA catalyst showed slower deactivation and maintained its conversion for 42 h, while CuNi/Al2O3 was completely deactivated. Enhancing SiO2-CA catalyst stability and lifetime may involve strategies like adding stabilizing metals to Cu-Ni alloy or reducing metal loading for better metal-support interaction. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is crucial for sustainable chemical and fuel production. This study evaluates the vapor phase hydrogenation of LA using Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts supported on various metal oxides and their impact on the pathways of LA conversion. Specifically, we examine the influence of AlO2, SiO2, ZrO2-SiO2, and CeO2-SiO2 on catalyst performance and stability. Cu-Ni catalysts supported on SiO2 modified with citric acid (SiO2-CA) exhibited superior stability, while the one supported on Al2O3 showed higher activity. The enhanced performance of the SiO2-CA-supported catalyst is attributed to its moderate acidity (379.3 µmol/gcat) and resistance to sintering. Stability tests reveal that although both CuNi/Al2O3 and CuNi/SiO2-CA catalysts deactivate over time, the latter demonstrates slower deactivation and better reactivation potential, maintaining conversion close to 80 % for 42 h. The study highlights the role of support in optimizing catalytic performance for LA hydrogenation.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Optimizing CuNi catalysts for long-term vapor phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone: Influence of the support on activity and stability
